comment: I was in intro to chemistry and the teaching was so bad half the class including me dropped out, i decided to take it online and figure it out myself, my teacher linked your videos to us in our course content and since then its been easier than intro to chem even though im in gen chem. Thanks chad!
Love the biblical shirts

Hey Chad, I hope you're doing well! I'm rewatching these videos in preparation for an exciting teaching opportunity and I want to make sure to polish my knowledge. In any case, I wanted to take this chance and say thank you for your amazing videos! I also noticed that you brought up Br and Cl as examples for the weighted average calculations, which is really cool since this concept is repeated again in orgo when we talk about mass spec. Out of all the textbooks/resources I've used, I've never came across a resource that specifically uses these two elements to teach atomic weight. These small details really help because they ultimately contribute to a bigger picture, and these connections help more than you may think.   Warm regards & I hope you take care.

I'm confused by the atomic weight of Oxygen.  If the two predominate isotopes are Oxygen-16 and Oxygen-18, how is the atomic weight just a hair below 16.  Wouldn't there have to be an isotope that weighed less than 16 amu to bring the average down?

The relative atomic mass of 16 is actually rounded! The most abundant isotope is O-16 which is 15.9949 amu and has 99.76% abundance. O-17 another isotope weighs16.991 amu and has 0.04% abundance and O-18 with 17.9991 amu is 0.2% so weighted the relative atomic mass of oxygen is 15.9998 amu. I hope that helps!

For such questions you are typically going to be provided atomic masses for a set of isotopes of an element (usually in a table) in order to calculate the average atomic mass that would be present on the periodic table for that element.  I would recommend using all the sig figs provided in such calculations and avoid rounding along the way.  Hope this helps!
